title: Business Live: Friday 18 October
text:
Getty Images Copyright: Getty Images

Sterling raced to a five month high - and according to Reuters has been enjoying its biggest rising streak since October 1985 - on the back of the Brexit deal on Thursday but fell back.

In trading during Asian hours on Friday it had eased back 0.3% to $1.2848.

Jane Foley, senior currency strategist at Rabobank, explained what had happened on Thursday: "It was around 10:38 when we saw sterling rise to up $1.2971 - we haven't seen that since around May or so. It was the pace of that spike... It didn’t last very long".

"It's all over the place. The market has been very short of sterling so when we have news that is a little bit more positive, those shorts are being covered," she said.

That is a reference to traders taking positions that assume the price of sterling will fall.

She said markets were now looking ahead to Saturday and the vote by MPs.

"There is so much uncertainty connected to Saturday," she said. If MPs do not back the deal "that opens up a lot more political uncertainty".

The pound is up 5% on the week.
description: The latest news, views and analysis from the world of business and global markets.
